description.narrative:
During the last decade, Mozambique have experienced a "Boom", on the extractive industry, with the discover of large quantities of important natural resources, from coal to Gas, from heavy sands to diamonds in the South, changing the context of Mozambique social,economic and political scenario forever. The importance of the sector is unquestionable, and different stakeholders, including CSOs, have been playing a role in advocating for a fair, transparent and accountable exploration of the natural resources.
Under this context, Oxfam, have started its program on EI, 3 years ago, that aims to promote access to information, transparency and accountability, through improving capacity of local CSO to better play their role as "watching dogs". Although, itis recognized that CSOs knowledge and capacity to play their role is still limited, and that is why, Oxfam, have been providing training opportunities to CSO, while also facilitating their participation on national and international advocacy platforms.
For the propose of this project, Oxfam in Mozambique will be implementing some activities, namely: (1) Run a training of 50 CSO members, Oxfam Staff and journalist on Cybernetic risk management; (2) Conduct a research on FLNG (Floating LNG) economics inRovuma Basins; (3) Support work on Investigative Journalism; (4) Support the revenue shearing mechanism (2.75% campaign); (5) Five EI local partners will be empowered on how to address gender on extractive and be linked to gender expertise organizations.The following stakeholders will be involved and will implement most of the activities (except the research): OiMZ, AWP (Associated Wistleblowing Press), The EI Platform, Resources for Development Consulting, The platform (AAAJC), WILSA, Muleide.
So this project, will act in other to feel the gap on issues that are not covered by current grants but have been identified as relevant for the sector and for our partners working on EI. The funds that will be used are the discretionary funds from the CO. The selection of this activities was based on meetings and engagement with both thenational platform, Oxfam affiliates, government and companies.
Expected outputs/outcomes a) A total of 600 people (40% women) of the community committees will directly benefit from FPIC training and there for improve their level of raising the voice to defend community rights, particularly for women. b) Around 1200 EI affected people from will ultimately benefit from a participatory method of monitoring resettlement and consequently improve the quality of their life. c) Decisions taken on resettled communities are gendersensitive.

participating-org.narrative: AAAJC- Associação de Apoio e Assist Associação de Apoio e Assistência J

The Association of Support and Legal Aid Communities (AAAJC) is an organization of civil society, Mozambique, based in the city of Tete, legally established in 2010 and with statutes published in paragraph 2 of III the Government Gazette Series (BR) .TheAssociation arose following the experience of 8 Paralegals Training course in Law of Natural Resources and Development conducted by the Judicial Training Centre and Judicial (CFJJ), the Ministry of Justice, in Tete Province in April 2008. the course enquadrava- within the framework of the implementation of initiatives of citizens' rights of access and use of natural resources, enshrined in national legislation as a mechanism to promote a just, equitable and sustainable development. After completion of the course, a group of former students met with the idea of ##creating an association that would help ensure access to justice for citizens and deprived communities, focusing on the area of ##access and use of natural resources. The association, registeredin 2010, was formed essentially by former trainees, or paralegals in law Natural Resources and Development.
AAAJC has as main objective: "To contribute in combating poverty, promoting social and economic development of communities and respect for human rights based on respect for princípiosº social justice, equity and sustainability" Bearing in mind the great pressure on land and natural resources that are currently assisting in Tete Province and emergence of private investment in the area of ##mineral resources, AAAJC defined as activities for achieving the above objective: i) monitoring the mining industry, being involved in recovery actions a permanent and critical debate on the development processes of Tete Province, ii) awareness, counseling and empowerment of communities, community leaders about their rights over natural resources, iii) mapping, documentation and mitigation (potential) conflict and iv) monitoring of social responsibility activities of companies, resettlement, among others, a member of the coalition on Transparency in Extractive Industries.
Colaboration with Oxfam started in 2013, when in partnership with Oxfam Australia, AAAJC participated on the research about the Impact of Resettlement on Livelihood of Communities from Mwaladzi. The report had a huge impact and was launched in both Tete, Maputo and Melbourne in Australia. Since there, AAAJC have been receiving support to train communities on FPIC (Free, Prior and Informed Consent) at community level.
